## Arpeggio: 9th in E

### Brief Presentation
An arpeggio is the notes of a chord played in succession rather than simultaneously, creating a flowing and melodic effect. In this case, the 9th chord adds an extra layer of depth and color to the standard major or minor chord.

### Notes and Intervals
The 9th chord in E major consists of the notes E (root), G# (major 3rd), B (perfect 5th), and F# (major 9th). The intervals between these notes are as follows:
- Root to major 3rd: A major 3rd (4 half steps)
- Major 3rd to perfect 5th: A minor 3rd (3 half steps)
- Perfect 5th to major 9th: A major 3rd (4 half steps)
  
### Genre and Musical Flavor
The 9th arpeggio in E can be found in various genres including jazz, funk, R&B, and fusion. It adds a jazzy and sophisticated flavor to the music, creating a sense of tension and resolution. The major 9th interval gives a dreamy and ethereal quality to the sound, often used to add a modern twist to traditional chord progressions.

### Songs
1. **"Cissy Strut" by The Meters** - This funk classic features groovy guitar arpeggios with 9th chords that drive the infectious rhythm of the song.
  
2. **"So What" by Miles Davis** - A jazz masterpiece that prominently showcases 9th arpeggios in the modal jazz improvisation, creating a cool and modal sound.
  
3. **"Lovely Day" by Bill Withers** - This R&B/soul hit uses 9th arpeggios to enhance the smooth and laid-back vibe of the song, adding a touch of sophistication to the chord progressions.
